conclusion: The problem involves shadows labeled A, B, and C cast by objects when a light source moves to the right.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area behind it. Their position and size depend on the light source's position and the object's size and shape.
There are three objects: a birdcage, a chicken leg, and two eggs, each casting shadows labeled A, B, and C respectively.
In the first image, shadows are cast in certain positions, and in the second image, the light source has moved to the right, changing the shadows.

The direction of a shadow is opposite to the direction of the light source. Shadow size depends on the distance between the object and the surface, and the distance between the light source and the object.
If the light source moves to the right, the shadows should move to the left, since they move in the opposite direction of the light source.
In the second image, the shadows appear to have shifted and changed in size.
Analyze shadow A (birdcage): In the first image, shadow A is directly below the birdcage. In the second image, shadow A seems to have shifted slightly to the right and become larger.
